clinical_study.brief_title: Acceptability and Feasibility of Finger Foods
clinical_study.official_title: A Mixed Methods Study to Determine the Acceptability and Feasibility of Providing Finger Foods as Nutritional Support for Patients After Stroke in Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: This study will investigate the feasibility of using a finger food menu on an acute stroke rehabilitation ward. This study has a mixed methods design, with quantitative, qualitative and economic components which will be used to inform a future randomised control trial.

primary_outcome.description: Number of patients eligible for study based on inclusion and exclusion criteria
Number of patients approached vs number of patients recruited to the study
Number of participants without fully completed outcome measures

secondary_outcome.measure: Dietary intake of participants over 3 mealtimes
secondary_outcome.description: Estimation of dietary intake over 3 mealtimes. This will include a standard mealtime and 2 meals when the finger menu is offered. This will be measured as energy and protein intake.

secondary_outcome.measure: Costs of implementing a finger food menu
secondary_outcome.description: A cost consequence analysis will be used to describe direct and indirect costs associated with providing a finger food menu.
Fidelity determined through observation field notes

other_outcome.description: Semi-structured interviews with participants to determine patient experience
Semi-structured interviews with staff to determine facilitators and barriers to using the menu on the ward

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Current patient on stroke rehabilitation ward
- 65 years or older
- Normal textured food
Exclusion Criteria:
- On the end of life pathway
- Partial or full enteral feeding
- Significant food allergies, intolerances or other dietary restrictions that could not be catered for by the finger food menu.
- Unable to give consent or no consultee able to consent on behalf of patient
- In a side room on the ward
